unnormalised: **What's the deal with Rental Yields? Is it the only thing I should look at when buying property in India?**
normalised: What is the deal with Rental Yields? Is it the only thing I should look at when buying property in India?

unnormalised: Hey everyone! So, you’re thinking about investing in property, right? And you’ve probably heard the term "rental yield" thrown around. Basically, it's like this: If you buy a flat in, say, Bangalore for Rs. 50 Lakhs and rent it out for Rs. 15,000 a month, your annual rental income is Rs. 1.8 Lakhs (15,000 x 12). Divide that by the property value (50 Lakhs) and you get your gross rental yield – around 3.6% in this case.
normalised: Hey everyone! So, you are thinking about investing in property, right? And you have probably heard the term "rental yield" thrown around. Basically, it is like this: If you buy a flat in, say, Bangalore for rupee fifty lakh and rent it out for rupee fifteen thousand a month, your annual rental income is rupee one point eight lakh (fifteen thousand multiplied by twelve). Divide that by the property value (fifty lakh) and you get your gross rental yield – around three point six percent in this case.

unnormalised: But hold on a minute, don't just drool over that percentage like it's a plate of hot biryani! Rental yield isn’t the *only* thing that matters. Capital appreciation (the property's value going up over time) is HUGE in India.
normalised: But hold on a minute, don't just drool over that percentage like it is a plate of hot biryani! Rental yield is not the only thing that matters. Capital appreciation (the property's value going up over time) is huge in India.

unnormalised: Think about it: A smaller flat in Bandra might have a lower rental yield than a massive villa 50 km outside Pune, but Bandra’s value could skyrocket in a few years, giving you way bigger returns.
normalised: Think about it: A smaller flat in Bandra might have a lower rental yield than a massive villa fifty kilometer outside Pune, but Bandra's value could skyrocket in a few years, giving you way bigger returns.

unnormalised: Also, don't forget expenses! Property taxes, maintenance (especially during monsoon!), and even just finding a good tenant can eat into that yield.
normalised: Also, don't forget expenses! Property taxes, maintenance (especially during monsoon!), and even just finding a good tenant can eat into that yield.

unnormalised: During festivals like Onam, rental demand sometimes spikes in Kerala, potentially affecting yields temporarily. So, seasonal factors matter too!
normalised: During festivals like Onam, rental demand sometimes spikes in Kerala, potentially affecting yields temporarily. So, seasonal factors matter too!

unnormalised: Ultimately, rental yield is just one piece of the puzzle. Do your research, consider your risk tolerance, and happy investing!
